commentBody: It was fun but fastest Sunday solve in over 10 years. Maybe that is why it was fun!
Very fun puzzle. Thanks!
Guess I’ll go back to the archives, I set aside more than 20 minutes for my Sunday puzzle!!
10 seconds from my all-time best, such a fun solve!
new pb!
A BAD RAP is either an unfair accusation or conviction (or possibly music from Vanilla Ice). A “bad rep” is a negative reputation. Or at least that’s how I’ve always understood these phrases.
Was there supposed to be an animation? I didn't see it after my solve.

Enjoyed the final challenge to find the key! 

I wonder now: what is the average number of Cs in a Sunday puzzle grid?

Like previous commenters, I posted the fastest time in several years. EXIT was my second guess for the keyhole, the first being ‘open,’ as in Sesame. 

Shout-out to Salman Rushdie, one of our finest contemporary writers, and in my top 5 favorite modern novelists.  Midnight’s Children is an enchanting read. 

[Fir coat] was a great clue. I could have done without Karl Marx on the heels of our Independence Day, but at least the quote was anodyne. 

Have a good Saturday night/Sunday, everyone.
I'm a huge escape room fan and loved the theme and extra steps at the end. Also got a Sunday PB breaking the 20 min barrier. (Almost as fast as my quickest escape room exit!)

I got the 2nd and 3rd letters easily, and guessed the other two, to complete the puzzle. Then I went back to the clues for letters 1 and 4 to understand better. The clue for the 4th letter was a real OMG moment.  I'm still trying to figure out how to get an E from ENDOFTHEROAD.
TIM TAMs - best biscuits ever.

Lived in Queensland for 5 months in 1996, so I have eaten Tim tams. Bested my average time but not my best. I thoroughly enjoyed the ease of the puzzle. The difficulty was solving the puzzle of the exit strategy. Well composed puzzle. Thank you

Honestly, I found this puzzle too clever by half. It seems like the constructors were so focused on getting the gimmick to work that they neglected picking really interesting fills and challenging clues. Sometimes the gimmicks are great (like a fairly recent once that forced you to solve outside the grid!), but for my money, this wasn't worth the payoff. In fact, I would have preferred the central code word to be less obvious, forcing the solver to interpret the meta-clues correctly.

How do I get out of the escape room? Mikey.

(Posting that pun was a lock.)

Thank you Zhou and Kevin! How fun that you construct together (and I agree with Kevin's simplification; the puzzle itself was on the easier side but oh man, figuring out that lock!) Really gave a sense of an escape room too. And thank you Caitlin for the push. I was stumped; read as far as the fact that you need to refer back to the puzzle, and got to the finish line.
Easy-peasy.

I have not read the column, nor any of the previous comments.
I have completed the grid, save for 69D.
There are now 456,976 possible options.
I don't get it.
I don't really care.
I suppose I will sleep on it, and maybe at 4:13am, it will make sense.
Or not.
Very tricky and enjoyable! Another way to solve “under the sea” is to use 54 down, since there is an I under SUBMAR.  Your way seems more straightforward!

Holy cannoli, that was fun! Swimming along hardly making any mistakes and thinking I'll make my Sunday best time. Ooooh, then spend 2x the time figuring out the lock. D'oh!

More! More!

I really can't believe all these "it was soooooo easy" posts.

I thought the body of the puzzle was easier than normal.

BUT the clues to the four-letter word were brutal.  I finally cracked it with the X in square four.  I had the T, but thought it was ducT, because of "end of the road".   It was not al all easy for me.

This, for me, was a classical example of more than half my time finding one or two letters.  

Clever, but I really didn't enjoy it very much.  Maybe I'm just grumpy because someone sold my country to someone else.

456,976 possible words, and somehow I stumbled on the correct one.

I will have to wait until tomorrow and let Lewis explain why I should admire this puzzle.
The usual danger of solving a Sunday on your phone - I spent more time finding a typo than I did unlocking the cell!

Is this the couple's first NYT grid? 

Or perhaps they create lots of Cryptic puzzles for UK papers...

Liked the “denture” one! Very fun. Needed to check the column, because I was thinking punctuation and numbers and all sorts of nonsense. But read slowly just to “get a clue,” and then I was a breakout star!

Came in eight minutes below average. The NW corner was the last to fall. I first tried "hole" in the keyhole.  Four square told me where to get the letter but as mentioned above that corner was eluding me. Once I got Marx and put in the X it was obvious. Clever and fun puzzle.
I thought this was very very clever. It really felt like an escape room with four tangential clues. I also thought the rest of the grid had above average difficulty for a Sunday, in my opinion.

Like you, I thought initially that "END OF THE ROAD" must mean "D"; and when I got the -XIT, realized it had to be "E." But 
I never made the "RODEO DRIVE" connection. I rationalized that, since the clue began "END OF THE," the "E" was the end of "THE."
Nice puzzle within a puzzle challenge.  Never heard of 82-down but a great Sunday crossword overall.
Possibly the funnest crossword I've ever played 👏🏼👏🏼

A puzzle within a puzzle? Are you KIDDING me? This is easily of the most unique and fun crosswords I’ve ever done. Incredible theme (obviously) but the cluing was also light enough that it didn’t bog down solving the lock in the center. So so so well done!!

I absolutely love a Sunday puzzle that shakes things up a bit. Solving the key clues was entertaining, even if the overall fill was perhaps a bit too straightforward. I was 7 minutes below my average including the disappointingly long period of time I stared at DXIT wondering why the key wouldn't turn. I hope there are more weekend getaways in our constructors' future because I'm looking forward to more workouts like this one.

Why are so many commenters revealing the answers? It's one thing if it was late on Sunday, but it's not even Sunday yet. Can't the editors write code so that if an answer is included in a comment that the comment doesn't get posted? All I wanted was a hint to the keyhole and people are posting the solution.

Im not sure it’s the E at the end of DRIVE, I think it’s the E after you pronounce the ROAD part of RODEO.

Also, I was expecting some sort of unlocking animation at the end. Otherwise what is the purpose of the spaces between 49 and 52 Across and 58 and 59 Across?
Ouch!  Too tricky for a Sunday.  Maybe not even for a Tricky Thursday.
New PB! 🔓🎉
Got it by guessing the last “key” word. Really a stretch - hated it.
Tougher than a casino steak

Clueless in Pittsburgh here (Tom Hanks plays me, and Meg Ryan plays my love interest in this rom-com about falling in love over a shared passion for crosswords), still locked in the room, having not figured out the EXIT thing. Oh well.

Really I'm here to comment on witches and gourds being warty. A bit harsh there...I know plenty of witches with faces smooth as porcelain and have rattled a multitude of gourds with flawless surfaces. Perhaps SOME witches and gourds are warty, but who is to say they all are, or that they do not have wens, cysts, moles, or simply growths, some benign, some malignant, and let us not forget tumors, nodules, beauty marks, boils, blisters, and excrescences? During the Black Death, the bubonic plague caused buboes or carbuncles, typically appearing on the groin, armpits, or neck and face, sometimes growing quite large. In advanced stages of the infection, the buboes might rupture and begin to ooze, and Bocaccio says they were quite painful. 

Regarding crones and hags, I cannot comment; but on the whole, enchantresses and sorceresses are clear-complected. Trust me on this. 

The child of a friend of mind worked summers at an escape room in Durham NC. We were privy to stories of dates gone wrong (commonly, one person getting out early and going home, leaving her date stranded and still inside), of amor in the chambers (yuck), of freakouts on ketamine, and of the liberal use of the rooms as latrines. As Samuel Goldwyn would say, "Include me out!"

I thought FOUR SQUARE meant to square the letter in the box on the answer grid with the "4" in the corner, namely X.  I thought, "Surely X being a Roman numeral that, squared, is another Roman numeral (namely C) is not a coincidence!"

But then what did ECIT mean?!?!

Sometimes a coincidence is just a coincidence.
The puzzle clues were a cinch (new best for a sunday) - but the "key" stumped me completely. Guess I'm Andy Refrain, not Andy Dufresne
This was a sweaty one!

The crossword aspect of this puzzle was only ok for me.  I’m not a fan of grids with lots of relatively isolated areas that have limited connection to the rest of the grid.  Those can be tough.  I guess that structure fits the escape room theme though — essentially a number of mini puzzles needed to get the final solution.  But I found the puzzle choppy and nothing really grabbed me.

The puzzle within the puzzle though was aces.  I briefly considered packing it in when I couldn’t quickly figure out the trick.  But then UNDERTHESEA clicked and when I saw that there was only one C I knew I was on the right track.  DOESNTHAVEACLUE led me to the dreaded hyphen clue, which had been filled in with TEE via crosses without me realizing it and the last two fell into place.
Loved this one. Got everything except the key. 🤦🏻‍♀️ Thanks!
Such a fun intriguing puzzle. Wonderful.

I was certainly stuck on DXC_ a while. Then DXIT. Knew it was Exit but couldn’t figure out the E. 
Lovely, lovely puzzle. Very fun!

Cool puzzle! 

I thought I had the wrong key so I started going down increasingly convoluted roads: four square -> X -> X marks the spot -> the only other X is surrounded by E's -> E? USE is below END OF THE ROAD -> USE = U's -> U? 

Finally gave up and realized I had gotten the key right but had STATESMaN/MIaN. Oh well.

This was for my 365 day streak. I had to run to the write-up to figure out what was going on in the middle. After reading the explanation… sure. You got me, Zhou and Kevin. I would not have figured that out (from the clues, at least — I might have eventually landed on it blindly guessing) in a million years. Hope your anniversary was fun!

_XI_ led straight to the EXIT, so I didn't get to wrestle with the much harder clues for the other two letters.  I would like to believe that personal best times on both Saturday and Sunday are a sign of expertise, but that opinion is belied by the fact that  "alternative to truth" baffles me. Please, somebody, explain it.

The only thing I had any trouble with in this puzzle was the key answer, because like others, I was sure 'END OF THE ROAD' implied a D, but I guess it should have been more obvious that it wasn't, since none of the other key answers were directly self-referential, but hinted at other parts of the puzzle.

The rest I found extremely easy, and I assume that was by design since the theme was a little trickier than usual.

Very fun! Finished 34% faster than my average Sunday, so I guess the cluing was relatively easy, but of course YMMV.

For the key: I got _X_T from a first glance at the clues, so the rest was obvious. Guess I got lucky.

Loved it. Hope we see constructors Zhang and Curry again.

Re: END OF THE ROAD:

Oh how the fancy have fallen. Rodeo Drive a mere “road”?!
The puzzle was a fun solve, but the end game/escape theme was too clever for me! Not a knock, just couldn't get there without help. I suppose it's good to get humbled now and again!

This was truly a blast. My husband as I have been doing a crossword each night while we wait for our four month old daughter to fall asleep. This puzzle had us excited - especially about the unlock word - and we both felt it was like an escape room before seeing the title. Thanks for such a brilliant puzzle and evening!

Kind of like that puzzle a few years back, a Sunday where in doing the puzzle you were actually playing a game of Clue.

This one did have the Escape Room vibe.  This wasn’t one of those puzzles you could successfully complete without figuring the theme out. For filling in the Key Word, you had to rely completely on your wits – no crossing letters to help you.  You had to crack the riddles to get out of the box.

Highly creative.  A tale of two puzzles – the fill-in and the get out, that is, the escape.  I loved this!

The clues were all easy, but the steps to get 69 down is just…not how my brain works, at all. Had to read all the hints, which made it pretty unsatisfying to finally solve. Not the kind of logic puzzle I like, so this was a big miss for me, but glad others enjoyed it.
Please don't do this again. Puzzle was fine. Exit key was too esoteric and tricky for me. Not feasible to crack. Not fun.
I was expecting something to happen when I completed it. Colors, flashing letters, some kind of whiz bangs.
fun!!
As an old maths teacher I read [Four square] as being 16. So, even after the hint about cross referencing, I was still scratching my head about X.
That must have taken a lot of effort to finesse.  Well done.

Great puzzle! Very intriguing and entertaining. 

I got the 'e' clued by 'end of the road' a different way. I took 'the road' to mean that we should see the column as a road and follow it to the end. Guess what letter is at the end of the column

I was pretty stuck on he word being 'tada'.     So I was ready to throw my tablet across the room, checking and rechecking the rest of the answers til I went insane.

Swallowed my pride and read enough of the article to get unstuck..   Glad I did as it saved me from going completely insane.   

Looking forward to a lively comments section.
Cool puzzle but there should be an easier way to find the theme clues at a glance. Perhaps clicking on one would highlight the rest of them?

This one broke my 15 day streak with no lookups because I could not figure out 69 D.  In my opinion, 69 D is just too cryptic. 

I am surprised that Will Shortz approved this puzzle. It's not a test of one's vocabulary or croossword skills, but rather a test of one's ability to figure out the WAY to far off the wall trick. Ugh. Not fair.  Boo, hiss, and a big raspberry.
Excellent and very fun puzzle!!! And the idea of there being only one C in the whole puzzle threw me but wow, impressive.
Really want to know what the purpose of the empty grey squares around the top of the lock is!! Anyone figured this out yet? Or is my phone just too old to see a cool anim?

Great job! Loved the challenge. I print it out and do it in pen so it was easier to find the four letters than I imagine it would be online. 

93A blew me away. I startled my cat when I shouted out, "ONE C in the whole puzzle?! Are you $&#@-ing kidding me?! How did they do that?!" I'm actually curious, Zhou and Kevin, when you decided to do that, how much of a burden/challenge was it to pull it off? Hope you see this!

I really enjoyed this one, the puzzle within the puzzle gives us an extra mental workout, but the lightly shaded squares above the center block really stumped me.  I completed the puzzle, and thought I had missed a trick.  I scanned the column and comments and found nothing that clued me in.  Then I took an another look at the grid and it finally dawned on me: it’s the shape of a padlock with a keyhole.

Good puzzles. I liked the theme -- okay I had D before E, and I spent way too long hunting for a named sea before noticing the single C, and I couldn't get FOURSQUARE until I read the column ... but d_IT didn't make sense and E_IT had an obvious fill

(Only I got "not quite" and so I came to the column to check if 69D was wrong. Only the actual problem was I'd originally had had Lite instead of LEAN, and EDIE proved that wrong but i accidentally only changed part of the word, LEAe.)

I also stuck for way too long with bmS for 17D, but neither bO_UE nor mR_SS made sense.  And wanted dAd for 13D, and misread 15D as "Rigatoni negative"... I had a few troubles lol. But not the fault of the puzzle itself.

Clever theme & finished almost 28 minutes faster than my average. Maybe it’s just me but I was expecting some type of animation when I was done 🤷‍♀️ like the “key” opening the lock? Or maybe I’m just spoiled with these crossword puzzles 😁😆. 
Bravo to the constructors 👏 & Happy Anniversary 🫶

My goodness, that was a fun, fun puzzle!  It was full of such funny, laugh out loud clues that took the edge off the difficulty and kept me plugging away.  I really enjoyed the challenge and the creativity.  I hope to see this duo's byline again.  Thanks for an awesome Sunday romp!
I thought I posted this earlier but I guess the emus blocked it. Anyone else have an initial guess for “number twos” that was less than breakfast table friendly?
Had to consult the column to understand the theme but otherwise enjoyed this one. Particularly liked the crossing of EVE/EDENS

I really thought something was going to happen with the blocked out, differently shaded squares above the key entry. A little disappointing to realize they're just aesthetics to make it look like a padlock. I think just leaving that area black would have been fine.
Oh my gosh, Caitlin! I fell into almost all of the traps you mentioned in the article (KANT, for example), except that I solved EXI_ and brute-forced the final letter!
Natick at 38D x 62A. Incomprehensible and irrelevant central key. Meh.
The vast majority of the fill was straightforward and easy; the theme, on the other hand, was just terrible: too convoluted by half, and not in the least bit satisfying.
Fun puzzle, and a new Sunday record at 20:19!

A Sunday grid dressed in Monday fills, all of which seemed to be in service of the four final letters. I was so weary by the time I finished writing all the letters in all the boxes that I wasn't up for playing a different kind of game to solve 69 down, so came to the column.

Forgive me if I seem annoyed, but I wanted to get away from it all and this didn't provide much escape.
Absolutely not. Will return tomorrow.
I loved this!! I solved everything without lookups until the final clue and once I read through the help here I got the rest of the word too! I’m proud! What a fun challenging puzzle

Got the puzzle pretty quickly, and got enough of the clues for the key to get EXIT.  But it was not solved.  Fixed sIDE to WIDE in 103D.  I was wondering what sARTY meant when I got it, but forgot to go back and check.
Cute puzzle and a fun theme! Happy Sunday, y’all.

P.S. I first discovered TIMTAMs at a conference in Sydney when I was a grad student, and have been obsessed ever since. Business trips took me to Tokyo for many years, and I discovered that Tim Tams were quite plentiful in certain supermarkets there. It isn't an exaggeration to say that I'd reserve 1/3rd of my suitcase for bringing them back to the states (though I now think they're quite easy to find here as well)

I did not reach the final step, so I had "duct" as the key word. I knew it was wrong before I even entered it, but it never crossed my mind to look for the solution in a third set of random entries. (I have no end game in chess, either.) So my hat's off to the solvers!

I thought all of the fill was very easy. However, I DOESN’T HAVE A CLUE about the key letters. Thought the SEA meant the letter C, and the END OF THE ROAD was the letter D.
Did a head slap when I read the column providing the explanation. Great puzzle
I’m so impressed at how the puzzle was created so there is literally just one “C” used. Those hundreds of hours paid off. Bravo!
So much fun! An easy fill up to the final missing word, and a lovely brain tease to figure it out. Perfection!
I am quite certain that the clue for 114D is incorrect. Should it not be “formerly concerned”?

Just solved and erased so my husband can enjoy this one in the morning :) 

I really appreciated all the clever wordplay and escape room theme — you can definitely feel the love that went into this puzzle <3 Thanks to the constructors for a super fun and clever Sunday!
We had a lot fun doing this one. Looking forward to more from Zhou Zhang!

FOUR SQUARE was obvious - it had to be an X. However, I'm way too impatient (and possibly not smart enough) to do riddles, so I ignored the other themed entries and just checked the column for the solution to the theme.

The fill was Tuesday-level. The theme was unenjoyable to me. So yeah, I did not like this puzzle.

It didn't help that going to an escape room is one of the least pleasant ways to spend time I can think of (I hate being locked up and I don't enjoy riddles), so already the puzzle's title primed me to dislike it.
A very unsatisfying Sunday puzzle.  The theme was  contrived, convicted and pretty pointless IMO

I’m most definitely on the “this was fun” side.  Has both TAU particle, discovered wrong a few times by Martin Perl before the final time that won him a Nobel, and his boss, already a Nobel winner, refused to believe the final time, and took his name off the authorship list on the discovery paper.

XENON too!

That was a very cute and enjoyable puzzle with a fun 'central' theme. Perfect for a relaxing Sunday morning. My only complaint, which isn't really one, is that I also hoped for a key-unlocking animation 😆

To all you Moaning Myrtles, I say BOOHOO to you and WOOHOO to me!

I’m a big proponent of puzzle-within-a-puzzle themes, so I can’t be mad at this one. Still, it was too clever for me. Like many others, I thought the “end of the road” would be a D, as would the letter under sea (C). “Four square”  is 16, so I looked for the letter in the 16 square and got A. I did correctly interpret T as the “clueless” entry, so yay? But in the end, DADT is not a word, so I didn’t make it out of the room. But that’s on me.

As for solving environment, it’s been another night of attempted dog soothing while the pops and whistles are cranked up to 11 outside. So on a night like this, it felt good—validating, even—to see my dog’s name in the puzzle. Not-Batman’s-Butler may be scared, but he appreciates the shout-out.
Fabulous! Just my cup of 76A phonetically!
This was so much fun! I gasped out loud when I figured out the third letter. Congrats to the constructors, what a delightful puzzle.

I’m glad so many liked it. The fill was fine with the exception of ROSIN and the MARX RUSHDIE crossing. 

The key was beyond my willingness to care. If a joke has to be explained then it has fallen flat. Not necessarily the fault of the joke. 

In any case, thanks.

Loved it! I really enjoy going in cold and working it out as i go. Obviously the clue was in the puzzle’s title, but it was still fun harvesting the final clues to decipher the “escape” word. Great work by the constructors.
This one might be my all time favorite crossword puzzle. Very cool idea with incredible execution. Bravo!!!!

Very very cool concept, love the build and I was excited to finish a Sunday so quickly and with only one "check puzzle" usage.

My only sadness was that the grey square didn't, like, do something, haha. After the "blinkers" puzzle earlier this week I was half expecting some silly celebration animation. Give a mouse a cookie...
Doesn’t have a clue described me once I’d finished the grid and was left with four unsolved key letters. Too contrived for me but congrats to those who solved it.

Brilliant! The theme clues really catch the essence of an escape room. I never figured out the first letter clue TBH (the letter was obvious), but the key for me was "UNDER THE SEA", that really unlocked things - an amazing construction feature by itself! As for the crossword itself, it was rather on the easy side, but enjoyable and fresh - no crosswordese.

Definitely one of my favorites! Kudos to the constructors!
Absolutely delightful. Thank you for this one.
Awesome! I wish it had animation with the key turning when the puzzles was finished.

Delightful puzzle from start to finish! I tend to lose my streaks on Sundays because — well — they can be a bit tedious to completely fill. This was very entertaining, with many clever entries and fun clues. Then the bonus puzzle at the end! And my favorite part… no stretching or crossing obscure proper nouns to make the theme work. Great job, can’t wait for y’all to submit your next crossword!

I really enjoyed this. At first I was completely puzzled and getting nowhere (DACA? some kind of political statement maybe?) then I re-read UNDER THE SEA and thought “no, No, there can’t _possibly_ be one C, can there?” And that unlocked the rest of the puzzle for me. I, like many others, guessed the E, but did figure out it referred to RODEO DRIVE - it’s the only road referenced, it’s pronounced road-AY-o drive in LA, etc.

Kudos to the constructors! I found your commentary heartwarming, and I look forward to your next puzzle eagerly!

Too easy for a Sunday puzzle, except for the "read the mind of the puzzle-crafter" central key which really had nothing to do with what a crossword puzzle is about.

For those who figured out the key, it was probably a pleasure.  But a real disappointment to me. 

3/10
Solved everything but the center clue, 69 down. Still don't get the logic even after reading the article. Good demonstration that not everyone thinks alike.
Puzzle simple except for the rather obscure key clues. Buy hey, it’s Sunday so I appreciate the challenge.

Very well done! It wasn't a difficult solve with the cluing and given the "Escape Room" theme, that was enough of a giveway that there was a puzzle within a puzzle. I solved in a half hour but the only clue I missed was "under the sea (c)." But by that time, it was obvious what the third letter was. Fiendishly clever and enjoyable! I hope to see more like that in the future.

Very charming, enjoyable puzzle! Lots of fun, fresh clues and a unique theme!  Very keylightful!!

Unfortunately for me, I solved in three parts, the third around midnight - just call me Sleepless in Utila - trying to not wake up my incredibly selfless and hardworking husband and hoping his mom sleeps through the night....  ERGO, I forgot about 109A, which I solved on the first part. I think the key would have come easier to me if id remembered it but instead I focused on the four themes right around the lock, thinking part of the trick was only having three instructions. 

I fell into the same traps mentioned in the column then decided to just guess... First door, then open, then alohamora - har! (Would be quite the rebus!), lastly, EXIT... 

I wish I'd have solved it from the clues but I do hope to eventually sleep.

Ms Zhang and Mr Curry sure are some constructor keypers!!  Thank you!

Is the “end of the road” supposed to reference the E at the end of RODEODRIVE, as Deb says, or the first E in RODEo? The latter makes sense to me, phonetically speaking at least. The former does not. 

My only gripe with the clue for E is that it’s typical to have a disclaimer that the clue is a “phonetic hint.” as in the clue for the letter I. My problem with this missing clarification for the letter E is not that it made the puzzle more tricky, but that it’s inconsistent.

22A - The First Amendment (the entire Bill of Rights, TBH) does not “grant” rights. It acknowledges and affirms inalienable rights postulated to exist. Sad to see this incorrect interpretation so close to Independence Day, but not surprised. It left a sour aftertaste offsetting this tasty ice cream sundae of a puzzle.

Knew before reading the comments this would be a lovely it or hate it kind of day. Personally I enjoyed the clever riddle although I had to come to the column to work out why the final I was correct. The fill was a bit too easy though
My partner and I have a 95% escape room success rate so I was determined to solve this. Timtam was one of the easier words as we have the (some would say) inferior Penguin biscuit.

Brilliant. Ignore all the complainers because complainers gonna complain. I knew from the moment of opening this puzzle and realizing what was happening that it was going to be fun, and I was correct. I loved this. I got the I easily, and the T after awhile when I remembered the mystery of the clue that was only a hyphen and went back to look for it. For the X, I didn’t know what the heck, and I was examining the two spots that had 4x4 grids for riddles, and then I went and read all the rules for the actual game four square before I figured out it was simpler than that. I had D for the E for the longest time. Thank you for this!!
I've never posted before, but I had to for this one since I loved it so much!

I dunno… maybe I’m just “old school”.  I’ve been doing the Sunday Puzzle for 55+ years, and I liked them better when the answers were actual words… not cutesy little phrases.  But I can live with the cutesy phrases.  Oh well….

The “themes”, though….   Most are OK, but OMG: I like crossword puzzles because they’re crossWORD puzzles.  Too arcane, and they’re not word puzzles anymore.  I like to spend half an hour on Saturday evenings with a crossWORD game… not deciphering the Enigma code!!!   Leave that stuff for another puzzle… another day. 

…and then TODAY’S (7/6/25) ridiculous “theme”!!!   Today’s was just plain stupid.  Really a waste of time searching for the absurd “key”.  NYT can do MUCH better than this.

Clever !  I managed to get « EXIT » but due to dumb luck.  I entered « X » because it seemed to be the only letter that’s kind of Four Square’ish.  Once you get the X, « EXIT » just follows.  Well done, merci!
Definitely the most enjoyable reveal of the theme I've seen on a Sunday, and brilliant construction for the clues to "escape" too. Superb work, well done constructors!
Clever theme! Lots of black real estate and three-letter gunk, so a Sunday PB for me.
I enjoyed this puzzle today. It was a bit frustrating but that's the challenge! :)

I honestly solved this one with dumb luck. After so many wasted attempts, I realized the key word could be EXIT, since you need an exit to escape a room. Thanks for the explanation, I really appreciate it. This puzzle was way too clever for me, but Fortuna was on my side today, thanks her for that 😄
The theme was executed flawlessly, the construction is brilliant, and the cluing is exceptional. Easily one the best puzzles I've solved.
Huh?

The theme is so attention-getting, two items deserving of praise re this puzzle’s construction may have flown under the radar:
•	A Sunday answer set containing just one C!  I was curious as to how many C’s are in the typical Sunday puzzle, so I looked up the number in all the June Sundays, and the average is 8.4.  Making a Sunday grid with just one C is quite constrictive, and Zhou and Kevin did it so smoothly, I’m guessing hardly anyone noticed, before the UNDER THE SEA riddle came into play.
•	This is a puzzle debut for Zhou, who came up with this theme idea.  High props and a hearty congratulations on that, Zhou!

The crossword part of the puzzle went by pretty fast.  For the key, I got the T first for 69D, so I guessed that the word would be EXIT, but one of my (many) rules in life meant that I couldn't stop the clock until I figured it out.  The X was easy to come by, confirming my hunch, but the other two required some work.  Last to fall was the E.  I really appreciated the trick as it turned what would have felt like a Monday into a Sunday.
Wow! Thanks Zhou and Kevin. Marvellous. Look forward to next time.

I'm not sure if this was The Usual Suspects or The Sixth Sense of crosswords. Yes, the clues were there all along if you go back and watch again (6th Sense), but on the other hand it's so subtle that they may as well not have been there if they were at all (Usual Suspects). I think this was a Usual Suspects for me. Great puzzle, but the clues were so subtle that it just felt like a gotcha ending.
When I solved the key (after giving in and reading through most of the hints), I felt like Ralphie in A Christmas Story cracking Little Orphan Annie’s “Drink your Ovaltine” code.

The construction here was impressive; I can't imagine the amount of work it took to come up with a set-up this clever. The clues for the four keys were definitely a worthy puzzle-within-a-puzzle, even if I got one only by accident (I took END OF THE ROAD to mean the end of the column that answer appeared in, which coincidentally was the right letter (E). But it seems that "Crossword Puzzle" is a closed economy; the more you put into "puzzle," the more you have to take away from "crossword."  Fun, but too little of the word play I come for, especially on Sunday.
The only disappointment for me was the lack of an animation upon solving! Other than that, chef's kiss!

I had a lot of fun with this puzzle. I got “doesn’t have a clue” and “four square” easily, but didn’t take “under the sea” literally enough. I put d, because it was the end of the downward “seed” and through the “d” was under the “see”

I’m on the love side of the fence. I love all types of puzzles as does my entire family. We always have a jigsaw puzzle out that everyone is working on. Once it’s completed, we bring out the next one. We do escape rooms together wherever we travel. It’s great family bonding time and each clue within those rooms seems to cater to one of our strengths. Needless to say, this one was right up my alley. Thank you, Zhou and Kevin. I wholeheartedly enjoyed this one 😍😍😍

Ugh, no thanks.

(Maybe it's just the current state of the world... but maybe not.)
I had (Thomas) MORE for 1A before realizing that 1D was also MORE.

wow!!! i loved this. i definitely had to guess the key word and then race over to this column to find out how the "E" and the "T" worked. wish i had stuck it out longer to crack them myself, since a puzzle this clever is rare!

Brutal. I had no problems swiftly solving the rest of the puzzle, but the lock thoroughly stumped me. I wouldn’t have been able to figure it out without checking Wordplay (the “ If you’d like a more specific hint,” section did the trick).
Big big thanks to the constructors. Many smiles while filling the grid. Fun concept.

I was very tired last night and was out of patience for 69D. I saw the clueless letter and the four square letter, and assumed the word had to be EXIT. And so it was. 

I knew that the other two were just more of a “search for hidden treasure” game I didn’t feel like playing. It was clever that the sea, or rather the C, was the only one. And was surprised that “end of the road” wasn’t D, but saw there was a road in the puzzle. So points for cleverness. Maybe more fun if you’re not tired.

The crossword itself was a smidge too easy and I solved it in way less time than I usually do for a Sunday.... Which  was a mixed blasting, as I love to vane glory but also to savor my Sunday crossword. The trick part was too much though. I don't like any escape room things and I absolutely had to read the article in order to figure this one out. 

Additionally, 121 across, Odd Pair. I still don't understand that one? I'm sure I'll slap my forehead when I'm enlightened but for now I'm stumped.

Glad to be out of this one. Cute idea, but not all that much fun for me. An awful lot of 3-letter entries to support the grid design. 

It would have been very helpful if, when we clicked on one of the four keyhole squares, the corresponding clue were highlighted. Took me a long time to relocate the clues for those four squares. Maybe such functionality is not yet available?

I suppose the incredibly obvious EXIT was a safe choice for the "keyword", but I did enjoy making sense of the four clues.  DOESNTHAVEACLUE for the T was quite mysterious, since I got TEE from the crosses and never even saw the clue for 76A. I'm assuming that ENDOFTHEROAD refers to the E at the end of RODEODRIVE. The X and I clues were obvious enough.

Took me about thirty minutes, though I could have saved at least five minutes by just typing in EXIT rather than trying to locate and make sense of the four clues.
Loved this one! Thanks for a great puzzle.

Might be to time to return to my home planet. Had to cheat some to get through this one, and even then remained appropriately puzzled even after it was all filled in. No big deal - that's just me. Appropriate puzzle find today. I must have done this one but had completely forgotten it. Anyway... a Thursday from April 20, 2023 by Simeon Seigel. The 'reveal' in that one: "How this puzzle's grid must be rotated in order to read the answers to the starred clues, when written in 17-Across" CLOCKWISE and 17a - UPPERCASE And the four theme answers (I'll omit the clues): WEOUZHWZO EOONEOON ZOUUHEOU WUZWUOZZH Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/20/2023&g=11&d=D I'll shut up now. ....

After reading the column as far as the hint, I decided T came from DoesnT have a clue.  And the E from End of the road.   I didn't catch on to the real clued for those letters until I read the rest of the column.

I giggled while solving this one.
Actually chuckled. 
Audibly.

Hubby looked confused so I handed him my iPad 
and he said,
“Huh. Looks like you gotta open that lock.”

Most days I’d be a bit bummed 
the solve was so crazy quick. 
No crunch as far as my eyes could see.

Until the final four.
Crunch time!
Bring. It. On.

Was expecting animation on the solve,
I’m not gonna lie,
but this was a 💎 even without 
further fanfare.

Submitted my latest rejection
last night, but this one has me raring to go again!

Today feels good. 
Hopeful.
Silly.

Happy Sunday all!
Fun puzzle!
Wow, what a waste.
I managed to misinterpret UNDERTHESEA as a reference to 75D, where D appears under the SEE.

userDisplayName: Going Placidly Amid the Noise and Haste
commentBody:
Clues were unusually helpful, coaxing for a Sunday puzzle. I was filling things in quickly without pause. In several instances, they offered two hints where one was helpful enough.  

Impressive to learn (after the fact) that they avoided C as far as they did. 

I was able to guess the central/final word after being sure of the letter T.  Then I went and learned how they did it. 

Probably a fine enough puzzle but the hints were neither clever nor challenging enough, especially for a Sunday!
This was awesome! It felt very much like an escape room.

Not my favorite. I got the “Kids’ game” and “Doesn’t have a clue” and then figured out the answer. But I had no clue where the correct letters came from for the other two. The methods given for solving the other two were ridiculous. 

But I don’t like (or have the patience) for Escape Rooms, in general, so I admit my prejudice. 

Hopefully, next Sunday will be less clever, but more fun.
Solved only by guessing the key. But I liked the puzzle!
OK, I have everything but the middle 4 squares. I have FOURSQUARE, UNDERTHESEA, and (appropriately) DOESNTHAVEACLUE.  But now I’m just staring at it.

76 Across is NOT only solvable by the crossing clues: it is a dash, and a single dash is Morse Code for T. So while it is in keeping with the use of the dash as meaning no clue provided, there are two meanings of that dash.

I loved it. The fill and clueing were fairly basic, but the riddles of the lock were clever and the lone C itself was an impressive feat of construction. I also appreciate the lack of junk fill.  These are trade offs I’m happy to take on a Sunday morning.

This was too easy as a crossword and too hard/not what I signed up for as an escape room. Solved all the crossword clues in among the fastest times I’ve ever done, then was left with a non-crossword puzzle that was simultaneously dopey, uninteresting, and inscrutable. I can go elsewhere for riddles, this is the crossword, and while themes and games can be part of it they shouldn’t overtake the crossword element, which they did here.
Very fun and so well-executed. Great job to the constructors!

Wow, layers of intrigue in this one. I was under water at the end of my road without a clue. Took me some extra cogitation time to make my EXIT.

And, seeing J, Q, X, and Z, I assume this is a pangram. Haven't run the alphabet to check.

Bravo, Zhou and Kevin.

I guessed the central key, and then worked my way backwards. Impressive!

This brings me back to the good ole days of Flash-based escape-the-room games. I played hundreds of them. I wrote walkthroughs for them. I was a little obsessed. If anyone is looking for a fun escape-the-room type game, I highly recommend The Room 1, 2, and 3. I played them on my PC, but I think they're on multiple consoles as well. They have gorgeous graphics and tricky puzzles.
I solved it by guessing the key.  I had to read the hint in Wordplay to figure out the clues to the key.  Tough!

Well, I completed the puzzle, mostly figured out the KEY to the escape, but (honesty is its own punishment) cannot justify the final letter I entered.  (I know it's right; I just don'tknow WHY!)

PhysDaughter is still filling in her grid.  She is stumped by different clue/entry things than I am...in yesterday's puzz, she entered UNCANNY VALLEY at once, for instance.  She remembers the cattle-rustling trickery by the Greek rascal, while I couldn't think of any Greek mythological figures who were lighthearted and mischievous...they were always too busy committing adultery and vying for supremacy....

Now to visit the column....

I do puzzles for fun so I don't worry about how long it takes me to solve.  It was fun to mull over this almost completed puzzle while drinking my coffee this morning. When I had to move on to making macaroni salad for a picnic, I took a look at Gameplay and saw that each key clue leads you to another answer in the puzzle.  Once I figure it all out, I said to myself, well, if I had time to just sit here and look at it for a while longer, I would have eventually figured it out without getting that info from Gameplay.  That was a lie I told myself.  I never would have figured it out.  But I did enjoy it!

A certain type of person probably really appreciates the gimmick puzzle in this one, although I'm not sure how much overlap there is with people who really appreciate good crosswords, which this wasn't. Removing the challenge entirely from crossword part doesn't make up for the ridiculous challenge of the non-crossword part.
What's the significance of the gray square between TAP and TAU?

"106D Alternative to truth"
From the cross, I see that it starts with a D.  But no matter how many times I try writing in "-onald," there don't seem to be enough boxes.  :-(
I needed lots of help but so clever!

Robin Williams' impression of Karl Marx... "imperialism is the woist thing I ever hoid" 

Thank you to the Zhang/Curry duo for a very cleverly-crafted puzzle and for the nod to Spinal Tap. I think of Michael McCean's acting chops from Lenny, to St. Hubbins, to his brilliant performance as Chuck on Better Call Saul and all points in between. What a transformation, huh?

Wow, dees... my limited research on the word relating to the clue, culminating in a deep dive into the workings of a cyclotron. "Writer of Disco Duck" would have been too easy, I suppose? 

10D was such a great tribute to what we'd do in our muscle cars, or for a few, pony cars. The original pony cars weren't quite so beefy until later, but you get my drift (pun intended). Also, the 92D... nice memories of my '68 Ford Gran Torino GT, which was kind of heavy to continually peel out. But the purring of that 390/4bbl Holley... music, baby!

53D... Ha! It got Elaine blacklisted from Hop sing's. That's what you get for dating a communist.

I always related *bad rap* to having to serve time for NOT naming names. "Bad rep" fits the solution much better, but that would upset the lip reeders.

I was expecting the key to turn and all the secrets of the universe to be revealed, but nice job guys!
Your puzzle was fun and interesting. Thank you for a nice Sunday diversion. And kudos to your children, too.

Fun unique solve . I finished the grid quickly enough , and got the X as the second letter in the key right away . Should have had TEE easily as well , but after being dumbfounded by END OF THE ROAD ( yes I had a D ) I tried EXIT and got the gold star . Not the first time I guessed at a word in a puzzle I wasn't sure of and got it right - so I'll take it as a win. Brilliant construction in actuality.
Now this was a fun puzzle within a puzzle! I would love to see more “escape room” themes like this! Fantastic.

Well my streak is about to end at 427.  My brain just doesn’t seem to work this way.  Haven’t read the column or any other comments; I will walk away for a bit and come back but will hit check puzzle at that point or I will spend all day trying to figure this out.  Well done to those of you who got this one!
Would have been a PB by a large margin but I was stuck on “efit” for a long time because there were four squares with Fs. Doh! Im an idiot!

Congrats to the creators and their family! I thought this was fun and a comfortable challenge. I am glad to have such a start to the week*

For 76 Across, I didn’t read this as the only clueless entry — I had TEE already as in “T-Minus…” 

* especially after the news of the last several days, including that woven whole-cloth, preposterous, unnecessary, pathetic, and most of all entirely ineffective attempted hit piece by this paper on our next mayor about his college application.
I really liked the puzzle in a puzzle but...No animation? I wanted the key to open a potral and suck me into a parallel universe.  Oh well.  Next time 😁

I’m trying really hard to put myself in the shoes of people who absolutely hated this gimmick. I really am. I just don’t understand how people who like to be challenged by a crossword don’t like to be challenged in other ways. I will occasionally be stumped by a theme, go to the column or comments to find out, say AHA—and usually it’s fair but difficult, or even if I thought it was too hard today just say, well, someone was cleverer than I was. I suppose if you really don’t want themes at all go to a crossword site that doesn’t have them. But if you are going to have themes then it’s natural that they will be stretched or unusual or challenging sometimes—and if not then it’s just boring. To my brain this one was pretty clear how to solve and I get that it wasn’t to others (not a comment on intelligence, just people’s brains interpret things differently). So say,  I didn’t get it or too hard for me or whatever, but saying that it shouldn’t exist as a crossword because the theme was beyond you is a slap in the face of everyone who was delighted by it.
Yawn. Couldn't be bothered. Got everything but the "key" and just lost interest.

I spent 13.5 mins filling out a standard Sunday grid, then about 2 more looking through the hints for the middle. All I needed was the X to figure out the word which I assume is the easiest of the 4 hints. I am not in the slightest bit interested in looking back at the grid nor looking up how the other 3 work.
Glad to see that EDIE came out of hiding, and is behaving herself today.

I don't understand DEES for odd pair..
 I enjoyed the puzzle but didn't like the gimmick because I couldn't figure it out.  Of course I'm sure I would have loved the gimmick if I could have figured it out!
 From reading the comments it seems most feel this way.
Loved, loved, loved this one. Such a fun concept and a really smooth fill for me. Kudos to the constructors for coming up with this idea and making it sing. I’m here for the partner-partnership!
I solved but didn't have a clue about the clues.

Solved it in under half my average time. It was easy for a Sunday, but it was a pleasant surprise getting the gold star without having to pick through big the grid looking for one or two errors like I usually do.

I figured out X first, which easily led to EXIT. I went back to figure out the other three clues before reading the column, but I thought the "I" was the one under the sea sometimes shortened to "the MED." Are there intentionally two clues in one in MEDICI?

Like many others, I was expecting an animation and came here to see if it didn't work on my phone for some reason.
Not a great way to promote escape rooms
You want easy peezy after this puzzle? Strands #490 “My hero!” 🟡🔵🔵🔵 🔵🔵 Go comment in the Strands forum https://www.nytimes.com/2025/07/05/crosswords/strands-sidekick-490.html

I'm sure I wasn't the only one expecting this puzzle to end with an explosive animation worthy of BREAK-OUT STAR. And I thought that would be the only way to justify having so many black squares at the heart of this puzzle (and the number of short answers that required).

So, color me a little disappointed.  But still it was a nice Sunday puzzle,
Or rather...
Two, two, two puzzles in one.

Kept holding out hope for some kind of STARry display at the end. I liked a couple of references to breaking out - 34D ("Put a pin in it" - ATM) 96D (TNT - blow it up, maybe?). And the TAP TAU made me think if I pressed "T" enough times, something exciting would happen. But it was not to be :(

This was fantastic! It didn’t take me long to solve but it was definitely a range of emotions, from “Please don’t let this be the one to end my streak” to “That was fun!”

Also, I love the story of this couple. They sound like amazing people to know.
I loved the construction and the game - a nice “aha!” Moment when I got how to complete the center. A fun, easy Sunday!

Enjoyed this puzzle, although I got the key word without really understanding a couple of the pointer clues-- so I was glad for the explanation in the column.   (End of the Road-- cute!)
Also loved the Constructors' write-up; hope for more from any and all in their family!

Solved in about 1/2 my usual Sunday puzzle time.

Still, lots of fun, as usual.
No way I would have gotten this without the clue. Embarrassed that some found it easy. Streak intact but damaged.

Here was my key solution:
D (END OF THE ROAD)
4  (FOUR SQUARE)
C (UNDER THE SEA)
A (DOESN'T HAVE A CLUE)

No, it didn't make any sense.  This is the kind of puzzle that  crossword blogs were born to explain.  I really don't think I could have waited until tomorrow to find out what on earth was going on.  But the problem with having a crossword blog is that you have to figure it out so that you can explain it to everyone else.  There isn't enough money in the world to make me want to take up that burden myself.  Plus the fact that I couldn't if I wanted to.

A very complicated trick that went right over my head.

I loved the puzzle, and the aha moment of realizing that you had to search the grid the same way you night search an escape room was really satisfying! For me, this realization was immediately followed by the thought, "Wait, is it possible this puzzle has only one C?"

That's what I'm talking about! 

Thank you, cute constructing couple, for this thrilling experience!

39D. My understanding of a “bad rap” is when someone gets blamed for something they didn’t do. If that’s so, I don’t believe “bad reputation “ is a great clue. Perhaps “underserved bad reputation” would work. Still, you wouldn’t say someone has a bad rap—you’d say they GOT a bad rap, a raw deal.

I loved today's puzzle. The trivia were things a Sunday morning x-worder might actually know, most of the clues indicated familiarity with the English language, and some were slyly humorous! Only one clue (Pitchfork shaped letters) bore no relation that I could discern to the answer. I solved it without screeching or gnashing my teeth! (Ok, I did need help with the theme.)

I wonder why Caitlin was so sure that the philosopher at 1-Across was going to be Kant?  I haven't read all of his writings, but I'd be surprised if he had much to say about "bureaucracy".

I guess that he was the first (and only?) four-letter philosopher she could think of.  But then why the persistence to hold onto it?

Sigh and sigh again. First, I thought this was REALLY fun. I enjoy spending my time on the puzzle, so I very much appreciate any extra layer that lets me crunch on it a little longer. Anyone else recall the lovely experience as a kid of having a parent or some other smart and loving adult lay out a treasure hunt for you? It feels... special. Like they took the time to *create* something for you to enjoy and be engaged with. That's what a carefully considered puzzle puts me in mind of. These constructors worked together to put something fun out in the world for us to enjoy. 

Now, can they be sure that *everyone* is going to enjoy it? Obviously not, and I enjoy the different viewpoints on the puzzle - to the extent that they reflect personal opinions. Folks who don't care for the escape room experience, people who don't enjoy riddles, etc etc - that all makes sense to me. 

What'll never make sense to me and what I'll not soon stop commenting on is the folks who paint the puzzle or (especially) people involved with a broad and imperious negative brush. "Shame on Will Shortz"? Seriously? *Shame*? "Incomprehensible and irrelevant"? When are people going to learn that these kinds of comments say more about the commenter than they do about anything else?

Ms. Zhang, Mr. Curry: thanks very much for your efforts. I thought the cluing was more than generous to support lots of successes today, and even the theme clues were really pretty straightforward. Looking forward to your next.

Felt compelled to comment as there is so much negativity and just plain nastiness in the comments today. I'm happy to admit when I'm just not on the constructor's wavelength or just not experienced enough for a puzzle, doesn't make the puzzle bad or stupid.

This was a breezy delight, personal best by far and the reveal was a treat. I only missed the "D" in End of The Road, but the fix was apparent immediately.

So delighted to see Enid Blyton in the clues - her books were a mainstay of mine growing up.
Throughly enjoyed this puzzle. One of my favorites so far!! Helps that I enjoy escape rooms, too 😂
I really enjoyed this one! It was a nice change to have a relatively easy Sunday plus a really difficult (to me) puzzle at the end. And all very satisfying. Well done!

A fun, fresh challenge. Of course, that means I can guess exactly what the opinions of the Wordplay commentariat are. I think I’ll skip reading today’s comments to avoid all that unnecessary negativity.

Really disliked this -- I love escape rooms in general, but I want my Sunday puzzle to be a Sunday puzzle. Glad that I am not trying to preserve a streak or any speed stats. When something is this tricky/unusual, there should be hints available right there in the interface (not buried in the blog).

Very much enjoyed this—though I definitely got the third letter the wrong way.

I noticed that the “shackle” of the lock was effectively a sideway C, and that the I in YOSHI was directly under it—and even though that didn’t seem likely to be what the hint was going for, I knew that I was the solution. PROBABLY unintentional on their part.
This was an absolute DELIGHT to solve, I am always amazed by the creativity people can fit into a crossword! This is the type of puzzle that makes me want to learn how to construct them

Well, I got every clue right (except for having to look up the nattick at 62A 38D), but I totally blew the lock word.  I had OXCA, so I changed it to ORCA, but then I gave up.  Ironic that I changed the only correct letter!  

Giving up is OK with me!  I have 32 years of archives to solve, and I gave up on having streaks sometime during 2020, when I had a 257-day streak (I think).
Hmmm.  You can and should do better Shortz.  After running through it and finding typos, went straight to the answer “key”.

I'm always impressed by puzzles that I solve but don't know how I did it. I got the X and I fairly easily, so I realized what the key had to be, but my husband and I couldn't figure out how to find the E or the T until I started reading today's column, and then I understood why 76 across had no clue, and he figured out 113 across. Bravo to the constructors for this fun challenge. Would have been cute if the middle of the escape room had turned color when the key was inserted, though.

I’m peeved that the usual highlighting of theme-specific letter boxes, with or without asterisks or italics, weren’t incorporated in this puzzle. I figured out what these clues were supposed to help me solve, but going back to them over and over took me a lot longer than it would have if the boxes had been highlighted in yellow. I didn’t solve the 4-letter center clue, but I answered all the others correctly. The 15-20 minutes added to my typical solving time by the need to backtrack and scroll around repeatedly to examine theme clues and answers in relation to one another was a much bigger pain than the typical Sunday puzzle inflicts. Please be more consistent about providing visual highlights in the puzzle grid.

My first impression of the puzzle layout reminded me of the scene in The Master when Joaquin Phoenix's character is taking the Rorschach test. Overall I really enjoyed solving this puzzle! I was surprised to read comments from people thinking this puzzle came way out of left field for a Sunday NYT crossword... I mean, this felt clever but very on brand for Sunday puzzles.

I think the crossword creators made the middle key too simple, because as soon as I solved one letter for it, I knew what the word was. I believe that was intentional to take it down a notch in difficulty, but I wish the lock had been less obvious and really made me hunt for those four letters! Overall I greatly enjoyed solving and would love to see more from these authors.

This is one of the best crossword puzzles I think I've ever done! I'm a big fan of escape rooms. I think there could have been a bit better cluing regarding the fact that we needed to search the other clues for the answers, as that's fairly nonstandard, but once I figured that out it became a very fun scavenger hunt that absolutely approximated the fun of an escape room in my own apartment. Thanks for a great time!

I found this to be a game of two halves, to borrow a footie (soccer) analogy. Most of the clues practically filled themselves, so I left the crunchier ones til after our village fete. Running the bric-a-brac stall, I can’t believe that people will part with their money for complete tat 🤷‍♀️

Anyhoo, returning to the grid with a cup of tea and a much needed sit down I found I was staring at the empty boxes in despair. 82D and 109A total unknowns amongst others. Honestly, I’m not good at riddles so didn’t have a clue how to fill that lock, but I just assumed it would be EXIT. Nice to read Wordplay and find I was right, though I miss the joy of working out the clues.

Although this wasn’t a favourite for me, I’m in complete awe of people whose minds can construct such a complex grid. Well done.

The comments ahead of mine mostly speak of enjoying the puzzle and mention a lot of negativity in the earlier ones. It would take me twice the hour it took to finish the puzzle to read all the comments so I will stop now and avoid all the negativity.

When I saw the visual of the lock in the centre, I got excited to embark on this clever treasure hunt. I'm grateful that most of the surrounding clues were doable, leaving the deeper sleuthing until the end. Even though it may hurt my brain a bit to figure out tricky clues, it is always a cool feeling of admiration and delight to figure them out. This one I just could not- I guessed the 'key' word, but didn't get how it came together. That said, I still enjoyed the challenge and admired the complexity of thought, creativity and teamwork behind it.

I solved it all fairly quickly, except for the “E” in the  key, but I already had _XIT by that point so it was obvious what the missing letter was. I couldn’t figure out how to get there though, so I assumed it was the E before “ROAD”.
Loved this one! Very creative!  A good Sunday vibe.  Thanks

Great debut, and a very interesting extra puzzle on top of the the normal clues. My only aggravation was actually due to using the app version, which I normally prefer - since the key word at the center is part of the normal clues, it became much more difficult to step around the solved clues and keep them in mind as references than if I'd had the print version at hand. Oh well, just a minor technical draw back on my end, the puzzle was still very fun.

Count me in team loved this puzzle. The board was elegant and the experience of solving the final puzzle was incredibly satisfying. 

I especially loved that every one of the four clues to the key needed a different tactic, giving real escape room vibes in how there are different types of puzzles to solve to get out. And like doing an escape room with friends, each person is going to have a different strength and probably find a different "in" to the final four clues. 

My "in" was recognizing that UNDER THE SEA probably referred to looking under a letter C in the puzzle. My knee-jerk reaction was "ok, but how will I know which C?" When I scanned the grid and realized there was only one C in the finished puzzle, I was pretty blown away.
I love this puzzle. Good fill with a great theme… absolutely brilliant!

Loved it!  Admittedly, most of the grid was fairly easy for me - but that’s fine.  I did have a few wrong turns here and there.  Loved the extra layer of figuring out the key, esp the ‘C’ clue - quite impressed that a grid that size only had one ‘C’ throughout.
Very enjoyable for a Sunday morning.
I have never commented on a puzzle before, but i just love love loved this one! Such a satisfying solve and a fun challenge at the end. Bravo to the constructors!

This puzzle was definitely outside of my comfort zone, but I really enjoyed it. I had about 10 minutes of that sinking feeling my streak was coming to an end, but *finally* figured out that FOUR SQUARE referred to the letter in square 4. Then I figured out DOESN'T HAVE A CLUE  and that was enough for me to solve the puzzle. My only disappointment was not figuring out the rest of the key using the clues; I had to come here for that. I think this puzzle helped me learn a bit more about why some people are so frustrated by rebuses, which for some reason have never been much of a problem for me.
Wow, what a wonderful puzzle! Enjoyed the wordplay very much, giving shades of Blue Prince ;)
Nice

This was great even if I was consistently off the mark. I recognized under the C, and assumed it was a puzzle where each clue gave you a different letter, so the C had to go somewhere among the four blanks. Hi @GD! 👋

Co-constructor here (+ long-time lurker, first-time commenter):

UNDER THE SEA was one of the first theme answer/hint pairs we came up with, and it caused two major constraints:

1. We rejected multiple other potential theme answers because they had at least one "C" in them, and we had used up our single C already...
2. When filling the grid, Kevin deleted all the words containing C from our wordlist, and we narrowed down options for 12D to be words that ended in E, I, or T. This put more stress on the grid and fill for sure, but hopefully not in a way that was too obvious! We went through at least five completed grids before landing on this one.

I was really committed to the single C in the puzzle, because I knew how much I would enjoy that aha moment as a solver, so I'm so, so pleased by this! (Sorry to your cat, though. We have a cat too, and she hates being startled.)

P.S. My one regret from this puzzle -- I originally clued TIM TAM as [Popular chocolate biscuit from Down Under that can be used as a straw]. Kevin said that bit of trivia was too obscure, and I agreed at the time; now I wish I had insisted.

@Brennan

I love a good discussion of the nature of "rights", especially the question of "natural rights" that some of the founding fathers certainly believed in.

However, just what are these natural, "inalienable" rights (assuming that they even exist)?  Most Americans might cite "life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness" (whatever that last one might mean).
Others who were digging a bit deeper would point out that while affirming the "inalienable right" to liberty, the Constitution also permitted the institution of slavery to continue.

So much for the self-evident Truth of these inalienable rights!

But is "freedom of the PRESS" an inalienable right?  How about the right to bear arms?  

Is health care an inalienable right?  How about housing?  
If something is an inalienable right can limitations be imposed?
I don't know the answer to these questions, and I've spent a lifetime thinking about it.

But I'm happy to hear more about your correct (and other incorrect) interpretations of these matters.
